revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox software | name = Microsoft Security Essentials | logo = [[File:Microsoft Security Essentials icon.png|64px]] [[File:Microsoft Security Essentials wordmark.svg|225px]] | screenshot = [[File:Microsoft Security Essentials.png|300px]] | caption = Microsoft Security Essentials version 2.0 | developer = [[Microsoft Corporation]] | released = {{start date and age|2009|09|29|df=yes}} | discontinued = | latest release version = 2.1.1116.0 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2011|06|27|df=yes}}{{Cite web |url = http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=e1605e70-9649-4a87-8532-33d813687a7f&displayLang=en |title = Download Details: Microsoft Security Essentials |work = Microsoft Download Center |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 16 December 2010 |accessdate = 16 December 2010 }} Note: This web page contains wrong version information; however, downloading the installation package and examining its metadata and digital signature reveals that it is v2.1.1116.0 published on 2011-06-27. | latest preview version = 4.0.1111.0 | latest preview date = {{Start date and age|2011|11|29|df=yes}}{{Cite web |url = http://bink.nu/news/new-microsoft-security-essentials-beta-now-public.aspx |title = New Microsoft Security Essentials Beta now public |work = Bink.nu |publisher = Steven Bink |date = 29 November 2011 |accessdate = 29 November 2011 }} Note: This is the only publicly available link I could find, the one form Microsoft requires a login. | frequently updated = | programming language = | operating system = [[Windows XP]] with [[Windows XP Service Pack 2|Service Pack 2]]
[[Windows Vista]] and [[Windows 7]] | platform = [[IA-32]] and [[x64]] | language = English, Bulgarian, Chinese (Simplified), Chinese (Traditional), Croatian, Czech, Danish, Dutch, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese (Brazilian), Portuguese (Portugal), Romanian, Russian, Swedish, Slovakian, Spanish, Thai, Turkish and Ukrainian | size = '''IA-32:''' {{Nowrap|7.5 MB}}
'''x64:''' {{Nowrap|9.5 MB}}
'''Virus Definitions:''' {{Nowrap|64 MB (almost)}}
'''NIS definitions:''' {{Nowrap|0.8 MB}}{{cite web |url=http://www.microsoft.com/security/portal/Definitions/HowToMSE.aspx |title=Install the latest Microsoft Security Essentials definition updates |publisher=Microsoft Corporation |date=11 March 2010 |accessdate=15 March 2010 }} | status = Active | genre = [[Antivirus]] and [[Network intrusion detection system]] | license = [[Freeware]] | website = {{URL|http://www.microsoft.com/security_essentials}} }} '''Microsoft Security Essentials''' ('''MSE''') is a free [[Antivirus software|antivirus software product]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] operating systems that provides protection against different types of [[malware]] such as [[computer virus]], [[spyware]], [[rootkit]]s and [[Trojan horse (computing)|trojan horses]]. Unlike the [[Microsoft Forefront]] family of enterprise-oriented security products, Microsoft Security Essentials is geared for consumer use. Microsoft Security Essentials [[#Reception|received positive reviews]] upon its release. In September 2011, it was the most popular antivirus software product in North America and the second most popular in the world. ==Development== In 2005, Microsoft acquired security software firm [[Sybari]] of [[Hauppauge, New York]], and shortly thereafter released the [[Microsoft Forefront]] line of server security products. Microsoft then announced plans for a free consumer security product [[List of Microsoft codenames|codenamed]] '''Morro''' on 18 November 2008.[http://www.microsoft.com/Presspass/press/2008/nov08/11-18NoCostSecurityPR.mspx Microsoft Announces Plans for No-Cost Consumer Security Offering] It marked a change in Microsoft's consumer antivirus marketing strategy: Instead of offering a subscription-based antivirus with a host of other tools, such as [[backup]] and a [[personal firewall]], ''Morro'' would be free for all genuine installations of Windows not intended for business use (with an exception for small home based businesses) and offers protection against all types of [[malware]].{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7737520.stm |title=Microsoft to offer free security |publisher=BBC News |date=19 November 2008 |accessdate=4 July 2009}} [[Microsoft Forefront]] would be offered alongside Microsoft Security Essentials, with central management tools not present in Microsoft Security Essentials, which is based on Microsoft Forefront technology obtained through the acquisition of Sybari in 2005.http://blogs.technet.com/b/mmpc/archive/2009/09/29/introducing-microsoft-security-essentials.aspx Introducing Microsoft Security Essentials{{Cite web |url = http://blogs.technet.com/b/technetczsk/archive/2009/11/04/microsoft-security-essentials-mse.aspx |title = Microsoft Security Essentials |work = TechNet Blog CZ/SK |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |first = OndÅej |last = Å eveÄek |date = 4 November 2009 |accessdate = 16 December 2010 |quote = JednÃ¡ se o odlehÄenou verzi podnikovÃ©ho antimalware (tedy antivirus, antispyware apod.) ÅeÅ¡enÃ­ Forefront Client Security. Je urÄen pro pouÅ¾itÃ­ koncovÃ½ch uÅ¾ivatelÅ¯, jako tÅeba domÃ¡cÃ­ch uÅ¾ivatelÅ¯. OdlehÄenou verzÃ­ Client Security je proto, Å¾e sice pouÅ¾Ã­vÃ¡ jeho motor, ale neobsahuje nÄkterÃ¡ podnikovÃ¡ rozÅ¡Ã­ÅenÃ­. DomÃ¡cÃ­ uÅ¾ivatelÃ© nepotÅebujÃ­ centrÃ¡lnÃ­ sprÃ¡vu ani sledovÃ¡nÃ­, nepotÅebujÃ­ ani centrÃ¡lnÃ­ testovÃ¡nÃ­ bezpeÄnosti poÄÃ­taÄe jako je seznam sdÃ­lenÃ½ch adresÃ¡ÅÅ¯ a nebezpeÄnÃ½ch uÅ¾ivatelskÃ½ch ÃºÄtÅ¯. [''It is a lightweight version of the enterprise antimalware (antivirus, antispyware, etc.), Forefront Client Security solutions. It is intended for use by end users, such as the home user. A lightweight version of Client Security is therefore that, although it uses its engine, but does not include some of the corporate expansion. Home users do not need a central administration or monitoring, or do not need a central testing the security of your computer such as the list of shared folders and dangerous user accounts.''] }} On 23 June 2009, Microsoft opened a public [[software release life cycle#Beta|beta]] to 75,000 people in the [[United States]], [[Israel]], [[People's Republic of China]] and [[Brazil]]. At the time, Microsoft stated that Microsoft Security Essentials would be finalized and released before the end of 2009, in 20 markets and 10 languages.{{cite web |last=Foley |first=Mary-Jo |url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/microsoft/?p=3141 |title=Microsoft Security Essentials beta to be capped at 75,000, kicks off today |publisher=[[ZDNet]] |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=29 September 2009}} The final build was released on 29 September 2009.{{cite web|last=Mediati |first=Nick |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/172762/microsoft_security_essentials_launches_tuesday.html |title=Microsoft Security Essentials Launches Tuesday |publisher=[[PC World (magazine)|PCWorld]] |date=28 June 2009 |accessdate=29 September 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.cbronline.com/news/microsoft_launches_new_antimalware_service_090928 |title=Microsoft Launches New Anti-Malware Service |publisher=Computer Business Review}} Hardware requirements for Microsoft Security Essentials differ, depending on the [[operating system]]. For Windows XP, Microsoft Security Essentials requires at least a 500 [[megahertz|MHz]] [[Central processing unit|processor]] and 256 MB of [[Random access memory|RAM]]. On Windows Vista and Windows 7, Microsoft Security Essentials requires a 1 [[gigahertz|GHz]] processor and 1 GB of RAM. Under any compatible operating system, a [[VGA]] screen of 800 Ã 600 or higher, 140 MB of free space, and an Internet connection are also required.{{cite web |publisher=Microsoft Corporations |url=http://www.microsoft.com/security_essentials/resources.aspx?mkt=en-us&s=1#mainNav |title=Find out what you need to know about installing and running Microsoft Security Essentials |accessdate=29 September 2009}} === Second version === On 19 July 2010, Microsoft released a [[technical preview]] of Microsoft Security Essentials 2.0. On 16 December 2010, Microsoft Security Essentials version 2.0 passed the technical preview stage and was officially released to public. This version includes ''Network Inspection System'', a [[network intrusion detection system]] that works on Windows Vista and Windows 7 as well as a new anti-malware engine that employs [[Heuristics#Computer science|heuristics]] in malware detection. Version 2 can also integrate with Internet Explorer to protect users against web-based threats.{{cite web | url = http://windowsteamblog.com/windows/b/bloggingwindows/archive/2010/07/20/beta-for-next-version-of-microsoft-security-essentials-now-available.aspx | title = Beta for Next Version of Microsoft Security Essentials Now Available | work = The Windows Blog | publisher = Microsoft Corporation | date = 20 July 2010 | first = Brandon | last = LeBlanc | accessdate = 21 July 2010 }}{{cite news |url = http://news.cnet.com/8301-10805_3-20011194-75.html?tag=mncol |title = Microsoft debuts beta of new Security Essentials |newspaper = [[CNET News]] |date = 21 July 2010 |accessdate = 24 July 2010 |publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] |first = Lance |last = Whitney }}{{Cite news |url = http://news.cnet.com/8301-10805_3-20025993-75.html |title = Microsoft releases free Security Essentials 2.0 |work = [[CNET News]] |publisher = CBS Interactive |date = 17 December 2010 |accessdate = 18 December 2010 |first1 = Lance |last1 = Whitney }}{{Cite web |url = http://www.windows7news.com/2010/12/17/microsoft-security-essentials-20-released/ |title =Microsoft Security Essentials 2.0 Released |work = Windows 7 News |date = 17 December 2010 |first1 = Robert |last1 = Boland |accessdate = 18 December 2010 }}{{Cite web |url = http://www.lifehacker.com.au/2010/12/microsoft-security-essentials-2-released-still-the-best-antivirus/ |title = Microsoft Security Essentials 2 Released, Still The Best AntiVirus |work = [[Lifehacker]] |publisher = Allure Media |first1 = Whitson |last1 = Gordon |date = 17 December 2010 |accessdate = 18 December 2010 }} === Future === On 13 September 2011, at the Microsoft BUILD conference in [[Anaheim, California]], Microsoft announced it will be integrating built-in anti-malware features in the upcoming version of Windows, codenamed [[Windows 8]]. Microsoft also showed that this new antivirus is capable of preventing an infected [[USB flash memory]] from compromising the system during the boot process.{{cite web|last=Whitney|first=Lance|title=Windows 8 to offer built-in malware protection|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-10805_3-20106681-75/windows-8-to-offer-built-in-malware-protection/|work=[[CNET]]|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=15 September 2011|date=13 September 2011}}{{cite web|last=Kingsley-Hughes|first=Adrian|title=Windows 8 will ship with built-in antivirus protection|work=[[ZDNet]]|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=15 September 2011|date=13 September 2011}} On 18 November 2011, Microsoft sent invitations to potential participants to invite them to a limited beta test of the next version of Microsoft Security Essentials.{{cite news|last=Foley|first=Mary-Jo|title=Microsoft seeks testers for limited beta of next-gen Security Essentials|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-seeks-testers-for-limited-beta-of-next-gen-security-essentials/11241|accessdate=19 November 2011|newspaper=All About Microsoft|date=18 November 2011|agency=[[ZDNet]]|publisher=CBS Interactive}}{{cite web|last=Thomas|first=Orin|title=New Microsoft Security Essentials Beta program open|url=http://www.windowsitpro.com/blog/hyperbole-embellishment-and-systems-administration-blog-18/security/microsoft-security-essentials-beta-program-open-141335|work=Hyperbole, Embellishment, and System Administration Blog|publisher=Penton Media Inc|accessdate=19 November 2011|date=18 November 2011}} A corresponding page on the Microsoft Connect website allowed volunteers to sign up for the program.{{cite web|title=Microsoft Security Essentials Beta Program|url=https://connect.microsoft.com/site981|work=[[Microsoft Connect]]|publisher=Microsoft corporation|accessdate=20 November 2011}} ==Features== Microsoft Security Essentials is an anti-virus for [[Windows XP]] ([[IA-32]]{{cite web |url=http://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en/w7itprosecurity/thread/96f7e420-1ac0-4422-8d5f-ab7d7891e233 |title=Microsoft Security Essentials is now Final |publisher=Microsoft Corporation |date=1 October 2009 |accessdate=8 November 2009 |last1=Drew |last2=Frisch |first2=Carey |quote=It is available for XP x86, Vista/Windows 7 {{sic|x86}} & x64 }}), [[Windows Vista]], and [[Windows 7]] (both IA-32 and [[x64]]).{{cite web |last=Finkle |first=Jim |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/CMPTRS/idUSN1044924620090610 |title=Update 3-Microsoft will soon unveil free anti-virus software |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |date=10 June 2009 |accessdate=4 July 2009 }} It is designed for consumers and lacks centralized management features which are found in Microsoft Forefront Client Security. It replaces [[Windows Live OneCare]], a commercial subscription-based antivirus service and the free [[Windows Defender]], which only protected users from [[adware]] and spyware.{{cite web |last = Thurrott |first = Paul |url = http://www.winsupersite.com/win7/mse_beta.asp |title = Microsoft Security Essentials Public Beta |work = Paul Thurrott's SuperSite for Windows |date = 18 June 2009 |accessdate = 4 July 2009 }} Microsoft Security Essentials includes the same anti-malware engine (dubbed "Microsoft Malware Protection Engine", or MSMPENG for short{{Cite web |url = http://blogs.technet.com/b/technetczsk/archive/2009/11/04/microsoft-security-essentials-mse.aspx |title = Microsoft Security Essentials |work = TechNet Blog CZ/SK |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |first = OndÅej |last = Å eveÄek |date = 4 November 2009 |accessdate = 16 December 2010 |quote = V pÅÃ­padÄ souboru ze sÃ­tÄ je to ponÄkud zajÃ­mavÄjÅ¡Ã­. Soubory ze sÃ­tÄ musÃ­ bÃ½t nejprve zkopÃ­rovÃ¡ny na lokÃ¡lnÃ­ poÄÃ­taÄ a teprve zde je skenovÃ¡n sluÅ¾bou Microsoft Antimalware Service (MSMPENG.EXE). [''In the case of the file from the network, it's a little more interesting. Files from the network must first be copied to the local computer, and only here is scanned by the Microsoft Antimalware Service (MSMPENG).''] }}), and virus definitions that all other Microsoft desktop anti-malware products share, including Forefront Client Security, Windows Live OneCare and Windows Defender.{{Cite web |url = http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/edge/microsoft-security-essentials-mse-released.aspx |title = Microsoft Security Essentials (MSE) released |work = TechNet Edge |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 29 September 2009 |accessdate = 16 December 2010}} Before installation, Microsoft Security Essentials checks for the validity of the installed copy of Microsoft Windows. Microsoft Security Essentials requires no registration or personal information.{{cite web |last=Bott |first=Ed |url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/Bott/?p=1067 |title=How good is Microsoft's free antivirus software? |publisher=[[ZDnet]] |date=18 June 2009 |accessdate=6 July 2009 }} Microsoft Security Essentials disables Windows Defender, since Microsoft Security Essentials also provides protection against spyware and adware. Using default settings, archived files are decompressed, and then scanned. File downloads and [[e-mail attachment]]s are also scanned. Its Dynamic Signature Service attempts to better identify malicious files by checking for updates if an application exhibits suspicious behavior.{{cite web |last=Hoffman |first=Stefanie |url=http://www.crn.com/security/218101208;jsessionid=AGWJBXGOE4NHAQSNDLPSKHSCJUNN2JVN |title=Microsoft Security Essentials Beta Reaches Max Downloads |publisher=ChannelWeb |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=19 July 2009 }} Before taking action against a suspect file, Microsoft Security Essentials prompts for user input. If no response is received in ten minutes, then the suspected malware is handled according to its default action, letting Microsoft Security Essentials determine what to do with the malware. [[System Restore]] points are created before removing found malware. Microsoft Security Essentials automatically checks for and downloads virus definition updates which are published three times a day to [[Microsoft Update]].{{cite web |last=Mills |first=Elinor |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-10268040-83.html |title=Microsoft's free antimalware beta on the way |publisher=[[CNET]] |date=18 June 2009 |accessdate=10 July 2009 }} Alternatively, users may download the updates manually from Microsoft Security Portal. ==Licensing== [[File:Microsoft Security Essentials Genuine Notification.PNG|thumb|right|300px|If the operating system is found to be not genuine, Microsoft Security Essentials will notify the user of the issue, and will cease to operate after a period of time]] Microsoft Security Essentials' end-user license agreement allows home users to download, install and use Microsoft Security Essentials on an unlimited number of their computers in their households free of any charges, so long as each computer has a [[Windows Genuine Advantage|genuine copy of Microsoft Windows]]. Small businesses are also allowed to install this product on up to 10 devices. The software license agreement however, denies the use of Microsoft Security Essentials in academic institutions, enterprises and governmental locations. The license agreement also denies the user the right to reverse-engineer, hack, decompile or disassemble Microsoft Security Essentials or to publish or disclose the results of benchmark tests of this software product to third parties without prior written approval from Microsoft Corporation.{{cite web |url = http://www.microsoft.com/security_essentials/eula.aspx |title = MICROSOFT SOFTWARE LICENSE TERMS |work = Microsoft Security Essentials web site |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 22 September 2010 |accessdate = 8 October 2010 }} Microsoft Security Essentials checks for validity of the operating system during and after installation. If the operating system is not found to be genuine, Microsoft Security Essentials will notify the user of the issue, and may cease to operate after a period of time. ==Reception== ===Industry response=== On 19 November 2008, after Microsoft publicly announced Microsoft Security Essentials under the code-name "Morro", [[Symantec]] and [[McAfee]] shares fell 9.44 and 6.62 percent respectively. Amy Barzdukas, senior director of product management for the Online Services and Windows Division at Microsoft, announced that Microsoft Security Essentials will not directly compete with other paid-for antivirus software; rather it was "focused on the 50 to 60 percent [of PC users] who don't have, or won't pay for, antivirus protection, antimalware protection".{{cite web |last=Hoffman |first=Stefanie |url=http://www.crn.com/security/212100928;jsessionid=FL5YJRP4Z50EAQSNDLOSKH0CJUNN2JVN |title=Microsoft: Morro Won't Compete With Symantec, McAfee |publisher=ChannelWeb |date=19 November 2008 |accessdate=4 July 2009 }} [[Symantec]], [[McAfee]] and [[Kaspersky Lab]], three competing antivirus vendors, dismissed Microsoft Security Essentials as a competitor, claiming that Microsoft Security Essentials is not as good as their own software.{{Cite web | url = http://www.itworld.com/security/79511/anti-malware-test-hand-symantec-swats-microsoft-security-essentials | title = Anti-malware test in hand, Symantec swats Microsoft Security Essentials | date = 1 October 2009 | publisher = ITworld (www.itworld.com) | first = Ellen | last = Messmer | accessdate = 21 July 2010 }}{{cite web |last=Keizer |first=Gregg |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9138667/Rivals_mock_Microsoft_s_free_security_software |title=Rivals mock Microsoft's free security software |publisher=[[Computerworld]] |date=29 September 2009 |accessdate=30 September 2009 }} Tom Powledge of Symantec claimed OneCare offered "substandard protection" and an "inferior user experience", implying Microsoft Security Essentials would be the same.{{Cite news |url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2008/nov/27/microsoft-morro-launch-onecare |title = Security 'hippos' dismiss Microsoft Morro launch |work = [[Guardian.co.uk]] |publisher = Guardian News and Media Limited |first1 = Jack |last1 = Schofield |date = 27 November 2008 |accessdate = 16 December 2010 }} Joris Evers, director of worldwide public relations for McAfee stated "With OneCare's market share of less than 2%, we understand Microsoft's decision to shift attention to their core business." Justin Priestley of Kaspersky stated, "[Microsoft] continued to hold a very low market share in the consumer market, and we don't expect the exit of OneCare to change the playing field drastically."{{cite web |last=Vamosi |first=Robert |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-10102376-83.html |title=Antivirus firms shrug at Microsoft's free security suite |publisher=[[CNET]] |date=19 November 2008 |accessdate=6 July 2009 }} [[AVG Technologies]], however, viewed Microsoft Security Essentials positively. An AVG Technologies representative stated, "We view this as a positive step for the AV landscape. AVG has believed in the right to free antivirus software for the past eight years." Nevertheless, AVG raised the issue of distributing the software product and said, "Microsoft will have to do more than simply make the product available." Despite its appreciation of Microsoft Security Essentials as a free product, AVG Technologies stated that integration of Microsoft Security Essentials with [[Microsoft Windows]] would be a violation of [[competition law]].{{cite web |last=Fried |first=Ina |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-10101652-56.html |title=Will Microsoft's antivirus move draw antitrust fire? |publisher=[[CNET]] |date=18 November 2008 |accessdate=6 July 2009 }} McAfee and [[Sophos]] both affirmed that an antitrust lawsuit would surely have followed if Microsoft had bundled Microsoft Security Essentials with Windows.{{cite new |last=Schofield |first=Jack |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/blog/2009/jun/11/microsoft-morro-antivirus |title=Waiting for Morro: Microsoft's free anti-virus software |work = [[Guardian.co.uk]] |publisher = Guardian News and Media Limited |date=11 June 2009 |accessdate=6 July 2009 }} On 10 June 2009, Microsoft announced that a beta version of Microsoft Security Essentials would be released in a near future but did not specify a date; subsequently Microsoft shares grew by 2.1 percent. Both Symantec and McAfee shares fell by 0.5 percent and 1.3 percent respectively. Daniel Ives, an analyst with [[FBR Capital Markets]] said Microsoft Security Essentials would be a "long-term competitive threat", though near-term impact would be negligible. Finally, on 2 October 2009, Avast Software a.s. (developer of [[avast!]]) commented that it has an ambivalent view towards Microsoft Security Essentials. "MSE is not the silver bullet but it is also not the bad sequel to One Care that some claim," said Vincent Steckler, Avast Software CEO.{{cite web |url = http://blog.avast.com/2009/10/02/and-what-about-microsoft-security-essentials%E2%80%94mse/ |title = And what about Microsoft Security EssentialsâMSE? |work = avast! blog |publisher = Avast Software a.s |first = Vincent |last = Steckler |date = 2 October 2009 |accessdate = 20 September 2010 }} ===Reviews=== [[File:MSE Threat Alert.png|thumb|right|300px|A pop-up notification stating malware was found.]] The public beta received several positive reviews, citing its low resource usage, straightforward [[user interface]], and [[price point]].{{cite web |last = Rubenking |first = Neil J. |url = http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2348998,00.asp |title = Microsoft Security Essentials beta |publisher = [[PC Magazine]] |date = 18 June 2009 |accessdate = 10 July 2009 }}{{cite web |last=Mediati |first=Nick |url= http://www.pcworld.com/article/167249/microsoft_security_essentials_basic_automatic_protection.html |title=Microsoft Security Essentials: Basic, Automatic Protection |publisher=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=10 July 2009 }}{{cite web |last=Krebs |first=Brian |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/securityfix/2009/06/microsoft_debuts_free_antiviru.html |title=Microsoft Debuts Free Antivirus Software Beta |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=10 July 2009 }}{{cite web |last=Angad |first=Ulhas M. |url=http://www.satishsays.com/2009/10/17/microsoft-security-essentials-anti-virusreview/ |title=Microsoft Security Essentials Review |publisher=Satishsays.com |date = 17 October 2009 |accessdate=8 October 2009 }} Brian Krebs of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that a "quick scan" took about 10 minutes, and a "full scan" about 45 minutes on an installation of [[Windows 7]]. [[Ars Technica]] reviewed it positively, citing its organized interface, low resource usage, and its status as [[freeware]].{{cite web |last=Protalinski |first=Emil |url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/09/first-look-microsoft-security-essentials-impresses.ars |title=First look: Microsoft Security Essentials impresses |publisher=[[Ars Technica]] |date=29 September 2009 |accessdate=30 September 2009 }} ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'' noted its "clear-cut" and "cleanly designed" tabbed [[user interface]]. At the top of the main tab, the security status is clearly shown. The other three tabs allow users to manually update Microsoft Security Essentials, review its history, and change program settings. However, PC World found some of the settings to be cryptic and confusing. Settings, such as what to do when malware is found, default to "Microsoft Security Essentials' recommended action". There is no explanation of the recommended action except in the help file. The editor was also confused because Microsoft Security Essentials does not mention it automatically updates itself within the interface; some may believe they must manually update Microsoft Security Essentials through the "Update" tab. However, this was included in the final release. ''[[PC Magazine]]'' cited Microsoft Security Essentials's small installation package (about 7 MB, depending on the operating system) and its speedy installation. On the downside, the full installation occupied about 110 MB of disk space, and the initial update took 5 to 15 minutes. The editor also noted the fact Microsoft Security Essentials sets [[Windows Update]] into its fully automatic mode, which automatically downloads and installs updates although it can then be turned off again through the control panel. Installation succeeded on 12 malware-infected systems. Some full scans took over an hour on infected systems; however, a scan on a clean system took 35 minutes. Although the Beta release of Microsoft Security Essentials did poorly in PC Magazine tests, the [[Software release life cycle#General availability|official final release]] did significantly better in AV-Test.org tests. According to Neil Rubenking, a PC Magazine author, in an on-demand scan test that he conducted in June 2009, Microsoft Security Essentials Beta found 89 percent of all malware samples: It found only 30 percent of commercial keyloggers, 67 percent of [[rootkits]] and only half of [[scareware]] samples. The suite's real-time protection found 83 percent of all malware samples and blocked the majority of them: In this test, Microsoft Security Essentials found 40 percent of the commercial keyloggers and 78 percent of the rootkits. Later on October that year, AV-Test.org conducted a series of trials on the officially released version of the product in which Microsoft Security Essentials detected and caught 98.44 percent of 545,034 [[computer virus]]es, [[computer worms]] and [[Trojan horse (computing)|software Trojan horses]] as well as 90.95 percent of 14,222 [[spyware]] and [[adware]] samples. It also detected and eliminated all 25 tested rootkits. Microsoft Security Essentials generated no [[false-positive]]s at all.{{cite news |url = http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-10366232-83.html |title = Security Essentials fares well in AV-Test trial |newspaper = [[CNET Networks#CNET News|CNET News]] |publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] |date = 2 October 2009 |accessdate = 24 July 2010 |last = Whitney |first = Lance }} === Awards === On 7 January 2010, Microsoft Security Essentials won the [[PC Advisor]]'s ''Best Free Software'' award.{{cite web |url = http://www.pcadvisor.co.uk/news/index.cfm?newsid=3209444 |title = Microsoft wins PC Advisor's Best Free Software award â PC Advisor Awards 2010: winners announced |work = [[PC Advisor]] |publisher = [[IDG]] |date = 7 January 2010 |accessdate = 1 August 2010 }} Later, in December 2010, AV-Comparatives.org awarded Microsoft Security Essentials v1.0 the Bronze award for proactive detection of 55% of new/unknown malware, the Silver award for low false-positives (six) and the Bronze award for overall performance. Microsoft Security Essentials v2.0 was released shortly thereafter.{{cite web |title=Summary Report 2010 |format = PDF |url=http://www.av-comparatives.org/images/stories/test/summary/summary2010.pdf |work = av-comparatives.org |accessdate=26 February 2011 }} On 8 June 2011, PC Advisor listed Microsoft Security Essentials 2.0 in its article ''Five of the Best Free Security Suites'', which included [[Avast!|Avast! 6 Free Edition]], [[Comodo Internet Security|Comodo Antivirus 5.4]], [[AVG (software)|AVG Antivirus 2011]] and [[BitDefender#BitDefender products|BitDefender Total Security 2012 Beta]].{{cite news |title = Five of the best free security suites |url = http://www.pcadvisor.co.uk/features/software/3284387/five-of-the-best-free-security-suites/ |accessdate = 12 June 2011 |newspaper = PC Advisor |publisher = IDG |date = 8 June 11 }} ==Market share== One year after the initial release of Microsoft Security Essentials, on 29 September 2010, it had gained 30 million users.{{cite web |url=http://www.techradar.com/news/internet/microsoft-security-essentials-racks-up-30-million-users-719995 |title=Microsoft Security Essentials racks up 30 million users |publisher=TechRadar |date=29 September 2010 |accessdate=30 March 2011}} The ''Security Industry Market Share Analysis'' report of June 2011, published by OPSWAT, Inc. states that Microsoft Security Essentials has been one of the most popular antivirus products in the world.{{cite web|title=Security Industry Market Share Analysis â June 2011|url=http://www.opswat.com/media/reports/OPSWAT-Market-Share-Report-June-2011.pdf|work=OPSWAT Market Share Report|publisher=OPSWAT|accessdate=12 June 2011|format=[[PDF]]|date=6 June 2011}} According to the report, Microsoft Security Essentials had 10.66% of the global market{{rp|5}} and 15.68% of the North America market.{{rp|4}} The same report places Microsoft the number one antivirus vendor in the North America with 17.07% market share,{{rp|3}} as well as the number four antivirus vendor in the whole world.{{rp|2}} John Dunn of PC World, who analyzed the report, noted that the tendency to use free antivirus software is something new. "After all, free antivirus suites have been around for years but have tended to be seen as the poor relations to paid software." He named Microsoft Security Essentials as a source of influence for PC users to adopt free antivirus software.{{cite news |last=Dunn |first=John E. |title=Free Antivirus Programs Rise in Popularity, New Survey Shows |url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/229610/free_antivirus_programs_rise_in_popularity_new_survey_shows.html |accessdate=12 June 2011 |newspaper=PC World |date=7 June 2011 }} In September 2011, OPSWAT report indicates that Microsoft Security Essentials has become the second most popular antivirus product in the world, while remaining the most popular in North America.{{cite web|title=Security Industry Market Share Analysis â September 2011|url=http://www.opswat.com/sites/default/files/OPSWAT-market-share-report-september-2011.pdf|work=OPSWAT Market Share Report|publisher=OPSWAT|accessdate=30 August 2011|format=[[PDF]]|date=22 November 2011}} ==Rogue antivirus software== In February 2010, a [[rogue security software]] package calling itself "Security Essentials 2010" appeared on the Internet. This malware, designated ''TrojanDownloader:Win32/Fakeinit'', bears no resemblance to Microsoft Security Essentials except for the name.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.technet.com/mmpc/archive/2010/02/24/if-it-calls-itself-security-essentials-2010-then-it-s-possibly-fake-innit.aspx |title=If it calls itself âSecurity Essentials 2010â, then itâs possibly fake, innit? |work = Microsoft Malware Protection Center blog |publisher=Microsoft Corporation |first1=David |last1=Wood |date=24 February 2010 |accessdate=1 March 2010 }}{{Cite web |url = http://www.microsoft.com/security/portal/Threat/Encyclopedia/Entry.aspx?Name=TrojanDownloader:Win32/Fakeinit |title = Encyclopedia Entry: TrojanDownloader:Win32/Fakeinit |work = Malware Protection Center |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 2 April 2009 |accessdate = 18 December 2010 }} This malware reappeared again in November 2010, this time calling itself "Microsoft Security Essentials 2011".{{Cite web |url = http://blogs.technet.com/b/mmpc/archive/2010/11/15/new-year-same-old-rogues.aspx |title = New Year, Same Old Rogues |work = Microsoft Malware Protection Center blog |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 15 November 2010 |accessdate = 18 December 2010 |first1 = Hamish |last1 = O'Dea }} A more dangerous form of these malware rogues however, appeared in October 2010. This malware, designated ''Rogue:Win32/FakePAV'', closely resembles Microsoft Security Essentials in look and uses sophisticated social engineering to compel users into introducing malware to their systems, under the guise of five different fictional anti-malware products. This malware also terminates and prevents the launch of 156 different programs, including but not limited to [[Registry Editor]], [[Command Prompt]], [[Internet Explorer]], [[Mozilla Firefox]], [[Opera browser|Opera]], [[Safari (browser)|Safari]], [[Google Chrome]] and other web browsers, email clients, instant messaging clients, media players and entertainment software.{{Cite web |url = http://windowsteamblog.com/windows/b/windowssecurity/archive/2010/10/25/fake-microsoft-security-essentials-software-on-the-loose-don-t-be-fooled-by-it.aspx |title = Fake Microsoft Security Essentials software on the loose. Donât be fooled by it! |work = Windows Security Blog |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 25 October 2010 |accessdate = 18 December 2010 |first1 = Eric |last1 = Foster }}{{Cite web |url = http://blogs.technet.com/b/mmpc/archive/2010/11/09/msrt-tackles-fake-microsoft-security-essentials.aspx |title = MSRT Tackles Fake Microsoft Security Essentials |work = Microsoft Malware Protection Center Blog |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 9 November 2010 |accessdate = 18 December 2010 |first1 = Hamish |last1 = O'Dea }}{{Cite web |url = http://www.microsoft.com/security/portal/Threat/Encyclopedia/Entry.aspx?Name=Rogue%3aWin32%2fFakePAV |title = Encyclopedia Entry: Rogue:Win32/FakePAV |work = Malware Protection Center |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 9 November 2009 |accessdate = 18 December 2010 }} == False positive: Google Chrome == On 30 September 2011, a faulty definition update caused Microsoft Security Essentials to incorrectly tag [[Google Chrome]] as malware. The issue was resolved within three hours.{{cite news|last=Bott|first=Ed|title=Users report Microsoft Security Essentials removes Google Chrome|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/bott/users-report-microsoft-security-essentials-removes-google-chrome/4006|accessdate=1 October 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=30 September 2011}}{{cite news|last=Metz|first=Cade|title=Microsoft Anti-Malware Tool Mistakenly Snuffs Google Chrome|url=http://www.wired.com/wiredenterprise/2011/09/microsoft-anti-malware-tool-mistakenly-snuffs-google-chrome|accessdate=1 October 2011|newspaper=Wired|date=30 September 2011}}{{cite news|last=Naraine|first=Ryan|title=Faulty Microsoft AV update nukes Chrome browser|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/security/faulty-microsoft-av-update-nukes-chrome-browser/9515|accessdate=1 October 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=30 September 2011}}{{cite news|last=Samson|first=Ted|title=Microsoft security update treats Chrome as malware|url=http://www.infoworld.com/t/patch-management/microsoft-security-update-treats-chrome-malware-174721|accessdate=1 October 2011|newspaper=Infoworld|date=30 September 2011}} ==References==
